q.a: you have to mean what you are singing. so, an interesting trick sometimes is to improvise the lyrics. it's like in conversation, when you have a conversation, you are improvising the words. that sounds normal and good, where as if you read a transcript instead, you are reading someone else's words from a different time and place, and it usually sounds fake and wrong. it would take some strong acting skills to actually convince yourself that those words are real at the time you are saying them. but that's really the only way to get the voice to sound any good. is if your brain thinks you mean what you are saying. so the best fast-track to this vocal state, might be to improvise the lyrics. could be worth looking into. if you get used to how that feels, this might help you conjure up a similar experience somehow, even when you have to be on script

q.a: of course not. (the song was actually supposed to be called "it's the first day of school", but then i decided i'd rather not have something that sounds like such a nursery rhyme. especially after recently releasing 'at the airport terminal' which nearly actually is a nursery rhyme) At the time i was positively sure i was finally going to succeed at doing a 1 week schedule, which i had been pushing fervently for for several months already, and i wrote the next song extremely fast, pretty much on pace for 1 week schedule, but, as always, a couple days into song production i realized that 1 week is wildly impossible, as always. so then, as usual, taking it slightly slower, did some re-writes, and finished the recording in an average amount of time (similar production time as the previous 2 songs) but then, when i started on the video, let's just say there was a little tickle in my mind that was possibly trying to get my attention during the entire 2-week blitz schedule but knew it wasn't welcome, because in the 2 week schedule it would have been impossible..... but i decided to listsen to it, this time. and what the voice was saying is, 'one of these days you should actually START a video in 3D instead of just sprinkling little bits of 3D in. or else you're never going to really get any better at it.' so i did it for half a scene and it blew my mind, then did it for a couple more half scenes, and it changed my life

q.a: there is this one certain phenomenon which i already knew about, but found out it was even 2,0000000 times truer after studying the history of the entire universe. put it this way: 'Do you remember that one shocking breakthrough which totally changed everything?' ... was thinking of the internet, but then i realize, no maybe i'm also thinking of the discovery of electricity. or the sudden invention of book publishing. or the sudden invention of writing. or the sudden development of language. or the cambrian explosion. or the sudden existence of life in the first place. or like 100s of other major turning points, throughout our history all the way back beyond this species, beyond life in general, all the way back. this idea of being clueless for almost an eternity, then suddenly, you figure out the magic key to something, and then your progress is multiplied 1000x. then you go on for a while (seemingly a very very long time, but still 1000x shorter than the previous long time), until you find another magic key for that round, and then that amplifies your progress another 1000x...... do you see where i'm going with this... Extremely exponential nature here, and it seems to be the nature of learning, invention, figuring things out, etc... This theme of the 'extreme breakthrough' is repeated so many times throughout the history of our planet that it becomes absurdly impossible to ignore

q.a: a mathematical guideline for time signatures, supposedly, is that the top number is how many beats per bar, and the bottom number is what note is a beat. So, by that logic, 2/4 means 2 beats per bar, and a 4th note (quarter note) gets 1 beat. By the same logic, 7/2 (as if anyone ever uses that, which they don't) would mean 7 beats per bar, and a Half note gets one beat. But, here's the thing: usually, in actual reality, when the bottom number is 8, the eighth notes are usually going by too fast to actually 'feel' like a beat. But by the sheer logic of the 'beats' rule as described earlier, 6/8 *would* mean, 6 beats per bar, and the 8th note gets one beat. But, almost always, in actual reality, 6/8 is actually fast enough that it's actually felt as if the dotted quarter note gets the beat. So that would make it 2 beats per bar, and 3 8th notes per beat. So really, to properly follow the system, that would mean your top number should be 2, and the bottom number should be...um.... some kind of decimal (let me perform some calculations)... the bottom number would have to be about 2.6667. So really, in actually reality, the way 6/8 is usually felt, it should more accurately be called 2/2.667. But that would cause chaos all over society, so it's not written that way. But getting back to the difference between 3/4 and 6/8-- if you set your metronome to 120bpm, and count in groups of 3 clicks, let's say that's 3/4 at ♩=120. Now set the metronome to 80bpm, and count in groups of 2 clicks, and subdivide each beat into 3, so like imagine you are counting 8th note triplets in 2/4. 3 triplets per beat, 2 beats per bar. but, plot twist, imagine the small notes are actually 8th notes, and you are living in a universe where there is 3 8th notes per beat, and each beat is a dotted quarter note. This is what it would feel like to be in 6/8, and the tempo marking would be ♩. = 80. In 6/8 (or 12/8) the tempo marking is often marked in terms of a dotted quarter note. So anyway, to conclude, this is not written in any 'rule', but this is just the way it is in the real world -- 6/8, 12/8, and often 9/8, are counted as if the beat is happening on dotted quarter notes. again, the reason being that no one wants to write 2/2.667. And, you may be thinking, why not just put the song in 2/4 and use triplets, or maybe just 4/4, and use triplets. And this is a valid argument, and like i always say, when you are faced with a song with some kind of triplet or quick 3 feel, you just have to ask yourself whether you would prefer to be writing a lot of dots (for all the 'regular' beats which will have to be dotted) OR a lot of the number 3 (for all the triplets). It's a personal decision, and the more you get out there and see the kind of charts that are circulating in your world or community, you can make the decision based on what you think would be most familiar to your reader(s)
q.q: I'm sure you've gotten this question before but I don't understand the difference between 3/4 and 6/8 (time signatures)? Is it just the triplets? People (music teachers) always seem to emphasize how it's important that we know they're different but they never actually explain what the difference is.

q.a: i don't know yet whether you do your writing before recording or if you actually try to do songwriting in the recording studio. but if you are one of those people that tries to write while recording the track, then based on your description of the problem i would highly recommend getting your writing entirely done before you start creating the track. this does not mean you have to know every instrument and every sound etc, but, what i recommend, is that you know every word, melody, chord, every bar, most importantly that you know the exact road map from beginning to end. Then the recording process becomes a fun adventure for how you are going to deliver the song, and you already know the agenda for every part (every bar, not instrument) of the song. forgive me if you already do this. if you have, then my answer would be different

q.a: the most important thing to do is to make music that you actually like. a secondary strategy is to also listen to music that other people like. Now, you may have mis-read that and are now thinking "oh ok, you're saying i should listen to music that other people might like and then maybe try to make music like that, even if i don't necessarily like it" NO, absolutely not, that is not what i'm saying. When it comes time to make your music, you must do it exactly according to your own wildest dreams. But before that, on a different day maybe, in a different season, in a totally different section of the building, you were just casually listening to music that other people might like, purely for the hopes of finding more things that YOU like. This really has nothing to do with the 'making music' part, the listening is actually just for enjoyment. When it comes time to make the music, actually you might as well try to do something you like that sounds totally different from anything else you've heard before. or the same. it's irrelevant whether it's different or the same. but the important thing is when it comes time to make the music you have to do it the way you like. So you may be thinking, "so, you're saying i should just make the music i like and it doesn't matter if anyone else likes it" No, that's still not quite what i mean. what i mean is, making music that you really fully like is probably the ONLY reliable way TO actually guarantee that others will like it. Now still, you may also be thinking "so what are the benefits of trying to make music that you DON'T like, but you THINK others will like." Well, i think i can safely say that this does not actually get anyone to like it, but, this is where the confusion arises, it might make OTHER people THINK that someone ELSE may like it. so that's good for a free lunch somewhere maybe, but it will be a lousy lunch and does not compare to the lifetime of grade A lunches you can get if you ultimately just cut out the middle man and make the music you know is best

q.q: So i've developed a weird habit to make my head feel better. it started off as "night walks" and progressed to "long scary night walks"; picking places that are scary. i think this is because i have a need to feel strong and brave. after that it progressed to walking places i'm sorta not supposed to be, recently it has progressed to what is technically "criminal trespassing". there is a country club type place a few blocks from where i live, and i've been hopping the fence (it's short) and walking around a small part of the grounds for a minute and then leaving. this is very exciting to me cause i've spent my whole life being a baby afraid of authority and conflict, been fighting that since i was a teenager. These night walks are helpful for making my head feel better, But it doesn't seem all good. i get this really demanding nagging tension to keep doing More, and if i don't i'm gonna be a timid weakling who comes in last forever etc. Right now  it want s me to run through the entire grounds. It doesn't seem like it ends. you just feed it and then it wants more. So the thing about the nice 'i can walk outside and do whatever i want" feeling from goin' trespassing is it's fun and then i come down and am faced with The Usual(my ugly face and shit brain that wants to hurt me). I do a lot of music and words and started drawing recently. those are the things i REally care about, in a nice way. the things i think can save me. I'm not sure what i'm trying to ask. I guess i won't die getting caught walking around a country club and my brain plays up the actual stakes as high as it can. but that would feel so unbelievably stupid For a While after dealing with cops and paying whatever that way too big fine would be. it's like a distraction but it has legitimacy cause of how big and deep the nice feeling is after, if only for a minute. But then there is all the bad feeling inbetween. I guess i question how helpful it is vs how dumb it  is. i'v e been talking it out with myself and im struggling to deal with these feelings and what i should do about them
